results.title: Constructing reality: a film on film
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Altschul Productions, Journal Films and David Altschul
results.brief_description: The five key elements of film construction - film time, film space, perspective, rhythm and sound are discussed as we construct a film within a film about a sports car race. The film shows how the film-maker planned, photographed and edited sequences.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gilbert Altschul Productions, Journal Films and David Altschul

results.title: Constructing farm dams
results.brief_description: In some parts of Australia, farmers have to rely on seasonal rains for their annual water requirements, with the result that crops are often ruined due to low rainfall. In areas with a suitable clay sub-soil, earth dams can be constrcuted to conserve water to improve pastures and increase production. This film describes the principles and methods of dam construction recommended by the Water Conservation and Irrigation Commission of New South Wales.

results.title: Constructing cyburbia
results.creator_credit: Emma Byrnes and Victoria University Press
results.brief_description: A CD-ROM constructed as part of an interactive media course at Victoria University of Technology, Constructing Cyburbia is a documentary-style look at the linked sociological phenomena of home renovation and personal homepage development. The work uses interviews and examples to affectionately explore common elements and aesthetic styles of the personal homepage.

results.title: Constructing Australia (A)
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Real Pictures, Prospero Productions, Piper Films and Alex West
results.brief_description: The Sydney Harbour Bridge, the Kalgoorlie Pipeline and the Overland Telegraph were amongst Australia’s most significant civil engineering projects. “Constructing Australia” is a series of three films - “The Bridge”, “Pipe Dreams” and “A Wire Through the Heart” - that tells the story behind these landmarks in the construction of white Australian society. Combining dramatic re-enactments with archival footage, documentary sources, and interviews, the three films deal not only with the practical challenges and problems that faced each of the projects, but also reveal the personal triumphs and tragedies, the political intrigues, the human dramas and the social contexts behind these pioneering events.

results.title: Constitutional futures (A)
results.creator_credit: University of Wollongong and Jane Innes
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The final episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the potential future of the Constitution and the facilities in the current political system that could be employed to institute change. Through commentary from a range of contributors a variety of subjects are discussed including Section 128 of the Australian Constitution, the notion of a citizens referenda and how the community can relate to and have power in the alteration of the Constitution. These contributors include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Michael Coper, Dr Helen Irving, Noel Pearson, Sir Zelman Cowan QC and Sir Anthony Mason.

results.title: Conspiracy of silence
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Vladimir Valenta and Niev Ghira
results.brief_description: A dramatic film about generational differences that almost split a family apart. Anna, fifteen, dates Bill. Her parents don’t trust her. Jack, her brother, committed suicide a year ago. Her parents disguised it as a car accident. Tension builds between Anna and her parents until she attempts suicide. The magnitude of their problems prompts a family reconciliation. Dramatic, realistic, fast-moving, this film sounds an alarm on the subject of teenage suicide. Cast includes Murray Berg, Warren W. Sulatychy, Judy Wood, Robert Galbraith, Tommy Banks, Jana Lapel Millman.

results.title: Conspiracy in Kyoto
results.brief_description: Conspiracy in Kyoto is based on one of the most famous of the narrative scrolls painted by the Japanese in the 12th, 13th and 14th centuries. This scroll, the “Ban Dainagon”, painted by Mitsunaga in 1175, is the story of an innocent man, unjustly accused of a capital crime, who wins his vindication. The film describes in detail the burning of the Imperial Gate, which constitutes the actual crime, and the various episodes connected with the search for the culprit.

results.title: Conspiracy
results.creator_credit: Film Art Doco Pty Ltd, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Sue Maslin and Daryl Dellora
results.brief_description: ‘Conspiracy’ is a dramatic and thought provoking investigation into the bomb attack at the Sydney Hilton Hotel in 1978. It does so through stylised re-enactments and studio interviews and poses such troubling questions as how the bombers managed to evade a huge security operation, mounted at a Commonwealth level. ‘Conspiracy’ ponders where the bomb was made, the questionable preparedness of the bomb disposal unit, and the abandonment of sniffer dogs prior to the incident. These questions were first asked years ago, they are continuing to be asked at a Federal level in parliament.

results.title: Consolation prize
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission and Rivka Hartman
results.brief_description: A humorous short film. Rivka Hartman draws on the silent film aesthetic and borrows its stylistic tendencies to recreate a world full of slap-stick, fantasy and drama. Young Sally Shambles (Rivka Hartman) is a naive young lady whose readiness for love leads her into a number of predicaments with men, all unsuccessful. She daydreams about her prospects and potential loves, but just can’t seem to get the method right. Written by Rivka Hartman.

results.title: Considering crystals
results.creator_credit: Viewpoint Productions, Unilever Films, Peter Griffiths and Michael Crossfield
results.brief_description: Looks at the way a molecular structure can build up through the repeated unit cell into a crystal lattice. Explains the main types of bonding which produce different types of crystal structure; it then goes on to consider some of the ways in which crystal structure is controlled in practice. The film illustrates its points with examples ranging from the alloying of steel and copper to the control of polymorphism in fats and the crystalline structure of polymers in plastics and man-made fibres.
